review.title: Semantics for Possibilistic Disjunctive Programs
review.abstract: In this paper, a possibilistic disjunctive logic programming approach for modeling uncertain, incomplete and inconsistent information is defined. This approach introduces the use of possibilistic disjunctive clauses which are able to capture incomplete information and incomplete states of a knowledge base at the same time.
histories: 37 pages, 5 figures. To appear in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP)
review.COMMENTS: 37 pages, 5 figures. To appear in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP)

sections.text: Xiv: 110 6.07 76By considering a possibilistic logic program as a possibilistic logic theory, it is shown that this possibilistic semantics for disjunctive logic programs can be characterized by a fixed point operator. It is also shown that the proposed possibilistic semantics can be calculated by a resolution algorithm and the consideration of optimal refutations from a possibilistic logic theory. In order to manage inconsistent possibilistic logic programs, a preference criterion between inconsistent possible models is defined; moreover, the approach of shortening to restore the consistency of an inconsistent possibilistic knowledge base is adopted. The approach is used in a medical scenario.KEYWORDS: Answer Set Programming, Uncertain Information, Possibilistic Reasoning. This approach is a revised and improved version of the work to program a possible knowledge base.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This concept is based on a combination of ASP and possible logic (Dubois et al. 1994). Due to the natural properties of possibilistic logic and ASP, Nicolas et al. "s approach allows us to deal with reasoning that is not monotonous and uncertain at the mathematical level. Nicolas et al." s approach is based on the concept of possibilistic logic.

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: In this section, we present the terminology and definitions necessary to have a coherent document. We assume that the reader is familiar with the basic concepts of classical logic, logic programming and grids.

sections.heading: 2.1 Lattices and order
sections.text: We begin by defining some basic definitions of grid theory (see Davey LB and Priestly 2002) for more details. Definition 1 Let Q be a set. An order (or partial order) on Q is a binary relation ≤ to Q, so these conditions for all x, y, z, Q, (i) x ≤ x (ii) x ≤ y and y ≤ x imply x = y (iii) x ≤ y and y ≤ z imply x ≤ zThese conditions are respectively referred to as reflectivity, antisymmetry and transitivity. A set Q that is equipped with an orderly relationship is referred to as an ordered set (or partially ordered set). It is referred to by (Q, ≤). Definition 2 Let (Q, ≤) be an ordered set and let S Q.

sections.heading: 2.3 Interpretations and models
sections.text: In this section we define some relevant concepts w.r.t. semantics. The first basic concept we introduce is interpretation.Definition 4 Let T be a theory, an interpretation I is a mapping of LT on {0, 1} that meets the conditions: 1. I (a) = min {I (a), I (b)}, 2. I (a) = max {I (a), I (b)}, 3. I (a) b) = 0 if and only if I (b) = 1 and I (a) = 0, 4. I (a) = 1 − I (a), 5. I (b) = 0.It is standard to provide interpretations only in relation to a mapping of LT on {0, 1}. Furthermore, it is easy to prove that this mapping is unique due to the definition by recursion (van Dalen 1994).

sections.heading: 2.4 Logic programming semantics
sections.text: This section presents the semantics of the answer sentences, which represent a bivalent semantic approach.

sections.heading: 2.4.1 Answer set semantics
sections.text: By using ASP, it is possible to describe a computational problem as a logic program whose response rates clearly correspond to the solutions of the given problem. It represents one of the most successful approaches to nonmonotonous reasoning of the last two decades (Baral 2003).The number of applications of this approach has increased due to the efficient implementation of the response solution that exists. The following definition of a response rate semantics was initially defined in terms of the so-called Gelfond-Lifschitz reduction (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1988) and is usually examined in the context of syntax-dependent transformations on programs.The following definition of a response set for extended disjunctive logic programs generalizes the definition presented in (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1988) (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1991): Let P be any extended disjunctive logic program.

sections.heading: 2.5 Possibilistic Logic
sections.text: Since the approach is based on the theory of proof of the logic of possibility, in this section there is an axiomation of the logic of possibility in the case of formulas evaluated by necessity. Possibility logic is a weighted logic introduced and developed in the mid-1980s, within the framework of artificial intelligence, with the aim of developing a simple but rigorous approach to automated logic, in which the notion of total order / partial order is embedded in logic. Possibilistic logic is based on the theory of possibility. Possibilistic logic, as its name implies, deals more with the possible than the probable values values values values of a variable with the possibility of being a matter of degree.

sections.heading: 3 Syntax
sections.text: This syntax is based on the standard syntax of advanced disjunctive logic programs (see Section 2.2). We begin by defining some concepts for managing the possible values of a possible knowledge base. We want to point out that only finite lattices are taken into account throughout the document. This assumption is based on the recognition that in real applications we will rarely have a finite set of terms to express the incomplete state of a knowledge base. A possible atom is a pair p = (a, q).

sections.heading: 4 Semantics
sections.text: In paragraph 3, the syntax for any possible disjunctive program has been introduced, and in this section, a semantics for collecting these programs is examined, which is defined on the basis of the standard definition of the set of responses semantics (paragraph 2.4.1) and the theory of proof of possible logic (paragraph 2.5). Since sets of atoms are considered interpretations, two basic operations are defined between sets of possible atoms; also a relationship of order between them is defined: in the face of a finite set of atoms A and a lattice (Q, ≤), PS ′ = 2A · Q and PS = PS ² is defined in such a way that x • A ² PS and cardinality (x, α) are defined between them.

sections.heading: 4.1 Possibilistic answer set semantics
sections.text: Similar to the definition of answer-set semantics, the possible answer-set semantics is defined in the sense of a syntactic reduction. This reduction is inspired by the GelfondLifschitz reduction.8 Cardinality is a function representing the cardinality of a set.Definition 6 (reduction PM) Let P = < (Q, ≤), N > be a possibilistic disjunctive logic program, M be a set of atoms. P reduced by M is the positive possible disjunctive logic program: PM: = {(r): A possible transplant (B +), N > be a possibilistic disjunctive action, B + M}, in which that of the form B +, not B −.Notice, which (P) is not exactly equal to the GelfondLifschitz reduction.

sections.heading: 4.2 Possibilistic answer sets based on partial evaluation
sections.text: We have established a possible answer by considering the formal theory of proof of possible logic. However, standard logic has several frameworks for the analysis, definition and calculation of logic.

sections.heading: 5 Inconsistency in possibilistic logic programs
sections.text: In the first part of this section, the relevance of considering inconsistent possibilist knowledge bases is presented, and in the second part, some criteria for managing inconsistent possibilist logic programs are presented.

sections.heading: 5.1 Relevance of inconsistent possibilistic logic programs
sections.text: There are authors such as Octávio Bueno (Bueno 2006) who argue that consideration of inconsistent systems is a useful device for a number of reasons: (1) it is often the only way to explore inconsistent information without arbitrarily rejecting valuable data. (2) Inconsistent systems allow us to make better informed decisions about which portions of information are accepted or rejected. (2) Inconsistent systems are sometimes the only way to obtain new information (especially information that conflicts with ingrained theories). (3) Inconsistent systems allow us to make better informed decisions about which portions of information are accepted or rejected in the final stages. To give a small example, where exploring inconsistent information can be important to make a better informed decision, we will continue with the medical scenario described in Section 1.

sections.heading: 5.2 Inconsistency degrees of possibilistic sets
sections.text: To define a criterion between the possible response sets, the concept of the degree of inconsistency of a possible set is defined. We say that a set of possible atoms S is inconsistent (or consistent) if S is consistent (or consistent), that is, if there is an atom that is such that a, ¬ a-S case is possible. Definition 13 Leave A-SP. The inconsistent degree of S is defined as: InconsDegre (S): = {... Q if S is consistent ({...

sections.heading: 5.3 Restoring inconsistent possibilistic knowledge bases
sections.text: To restore the consistency of an inconsistent knowledge base, possibilistic logic eliminates the set of possibilistic formulas that are lower than the inconsistent level of the inconsistent knowledge base. In light of this idea, the authors of (Nicolas et al. 2006) define the concept of the α-section for possibilistic logic programs. Based on Definition 14 of (Nicolas et al. 2006), we define their respective generalizations for our approach. Definition 15 Let P be a possibilistic logic program - the strict α-section is the subprogram P > α = {r ĉP | n (r) > α} - the consistency intersection degree of P: ConsCutDeg (P): = 0.5 Q, if P ² is consistent, a possibilistic logic program is consistent.

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: Most approaches in literature deal with one of the following formalities: • annotated logic programming, e.g. (Kifer and Subrahmanian 1992); • probabilistic logic, e.g. (van Emden 1986; Rodríguez-Artalejo and Romero-Díaz 2008; Van-Nieuwenborgh et al. 2007); • multi-rated logic, e.g. (Fitting 1991; Lakshmanan 1994); • evidence of theoretical programming, e.g. (Baldwin 1987); • possibilistic logic, e.g. (Dubois et al. 1991; Alsinet and Godo 2000).

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and future work
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most people who are able are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they do not want.

referenceMentions.context: Answer Set Programming (ASP) is one of the most successful logic programming approaches in Non-monotonic Reasoning and Artificial Intelligence applications (Baral 2003; Gelfond 2008).
Answer Set Programming (ASP) is one of the most successful logic programming approaches in Non-monotonic Reasoning and Artificial Intelligence applications (Baral 2003; Gelfond 2008).
In (Nicolas et al. 2006), a possibilistic framework for reasoning under uncertainty was proposed.
This framework is a combination between ASP and possibilistic logic (Dubois et al. 1994).
Possibilistic Logic is based on possibilistic theory in which, at the mathematical level, degrees of possibility and necessity are closely related to fuzzy sets (Dubois et al. 1994).
An important property of possibilistic logic is that it is axiomatizable in the necessityvalued case (Dubois et al. 1994).

Equally important to consider is that the answer set semantics inference can also be characterized as a logic inference in terms of the proof theory of intuitionistic logic and intermediate logics (Pearce 1999; Osorio et al. 2004).

Equally important to consider is that the answer set semantics inference can also be characterized as a logic inference in terms of the proof theory of intuitionistic logic and intermediate logics (Pearce 1999; Osorio et al. 2004).

Since in (Dubois et al. 1994) an axiomatization of possibilistic logic has been defined, in this paper we explore the characterization of a possibilistic semantics for capturing possibilistic logic programs in terms of the proof theory of possibilistic logic and the standard answer set semantics.

In this paper, we extend the work of two earlier papers (Nieves et al. 2007a; Nieves et al. 2007b) in order to obtain a simple logic characterization of a possibilistic logic programming semantics for capturing possibilistic programs; this semantics is applicable to disjunctive as well as normal logic programs.

In this paper, we extend the work of two earlier papers (Nieves et al. 2007a; Nieves et al. 2007b) in order to obtain a simple logic characterization of a possibilistic logic programming semantics for capturing possibilistic programs; this semantics is applicable to disjunctive as well as normal logic programs.

The answer set semantics was first defined in terms of the so called Gelfond-Lifschitz reduction (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1988) and it is usually studied in the context of syntax dependent transformations on programs.

The following definition of an answer set for extended disjunctive logic programs generalizes the definition presented in (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1988) and it was presented in (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1991): Let P be any extended disjunctive logic program.

In fact, we agree with Bueno (Bueno 2006) that considering inconsistent systems as inconsistent possibilistic answer sets is some times the only way to explore inconsistent information without arbitrarily rejecting precious data.

• In (Lukasiewicz 2001), Many-Valued Disjunctive Logic Programs with probabilistic semantics are introduced.
• In (Gergatsoulis et al. 2001), the logic programming language Disjunctive Chronolog is introduced.
• In (Mateis 2000), the Quantitative Disjunctive Logic Programs (QDLP) are introduced.
• In (Baral et al. 2009), intensive research is done in order to achieve a complete integration between ASP and probability theory.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, a possibilistic disjunctive logic programming approach for modeling uncertain, incomplete and inconsistent information is defined. This approach introduces the use of possibilistic disjunctive clauses which are able to capture incomplete information and incomplete states of a knowledge base at the same time. By considering a possibilistic logic program as a possibilistic logic theory, a construction of a possibilistic logic programming semantic based on answer sets and the proof theory of possibilistic logic is defined. It shows that this possibilistic semantics for disjunctive logic programs can be characterized by a fixed-point operator. It is also shown that the suggested possibilistic semantics can be computed by a resolution algorithm and the consideration of optimal refutations from a possibilistic logic theory. In order to manage inconsistent possibilistic logic programs, a preference criterion between inconsistent possibilistic models is defined; in addition, the approach of cuts for restoring consistency of an inconsistent possibilistic knowledge base is adopted. The approach is illustrated in a medical scenario.
